Award.AwardTitle: Early Career: Acquisition of a Three-Spectrometer, High-Definition Scanning Electron Microscope for Research and Education in the Geosciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Missouri will acquire a custom-designed, high-definition Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) for research on preserved soft-body fossils from the dawn of animal life about 550 million years ago. High-resolution photos of mineralization that preserves soft tissue can expand the understanding of the evolution of animal life beyond the bones, teeth, or shells that make up the bulk of the fossil record. The new instrument can decipher what aspects of fossil anatomy reflect original biology and evolutionary significance and what reflect post-mortem decay, fossilization, and mineralization processes. Images from the instrument will be used in an interactive science-and-art exhibit at the University of Missouri Museum of Art and Archaeology.

The University of Missouri will acquire a three-spectrometer, high-definition, variable-pressure scanning electron microscope (SEM) to support research and educational activities in paleobiology and geochemistry. Highly accurate compositional analysis will be coupled with sub-nanometer imaging resolution to characterize the mineralogy of a wide array of Earth science samples. This instrument and associated personnel will support research on the exceptional cases of soft-tissue fossil preservation at the dawn of animal life across the Ediacaran-Cambrian transition, which is a time of close interaction between biological and geological systems. The early-career principal investigator will provide training on the custom SEM to faculty, postdoctoral researchers and graduate students as well as develop a museum program on the "science of the everyday world" for high-school students and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposal was to acquire a customized scanning electron microscope (SEM), specifically geared towards the analyses of geological and paleontological materials, at the University of Missouri (MU).

PI James Schiffbauer, an early career geological scientist and paleobiologist, has a significant history operating electron-, ion-, and x-ray- instrumentation across a diversity of sample types, though his primary interest is in the understanding of how fossils are preserved. PI Schiffbauer focuses on the exceptional cases of soft-tissue fossil preservation at the dawn of animal life across the Ediacaran?Cambrian transition (~540 million years ago), representing a prime interaction between biological and geological systems. Schiffbauer?s approach examines preservational processes on the shortest timeframes using experimental decay and biomimetic approaches to those of geological significance through analysis of fossil materials, and from the nano- to macro-scales. As soft-tissue preservational modes exhibit differences in biological fidelity, gaining a more complete understanding of how these processes proceed, and across the range of temporal and spatial scales over which they operate, will shed light on the biological information that can be drawn from these fossils. The acquired instrumentation was customized with the distinct purpose of extracting as much information as possible from fossil specimens with little to no preparation requirements (and especially including the minimization of destructive preparation). The SEM acquired is a variable-pressure, field-emission Zeiss Sigma 500 with dual energy dispersive X-ray spectrometers and a microspot X-ray fluorescence source.

The installation of this instrument afforded PI Schiffbauer to develop a course on microanalytical techniques for geological sciences, which is now regularly offered in the MU Department of Geological Sciences. In addition, PI Schiffbauer has been able to offer targeted short courses for early career researchers and advanced graduate students, where researchers visit MU?s campus and are able to immersively learn about microanalytical techniques as applied to their own sample materials. These educational efforts have had marked success for students to gain analytical microscopy experience and understanding, and have thus far yielded several important discoveries to be published.  

This project also supported the hiring of technical support, Dr. Tara Selly, who has now formally moved to a permanent Research Assistant Professorship at MU. Finally, through the opportunities provided by the funding of this instrument acquisition, PI Schiffbauer and MU colleagues embarked on a substantial fundraising campaign across campus ? which ultimately resulted in the acquisition of a second instrument, a Zeiss Xradia 510 Versa X-ray tomographic microscope, and the development of MU?s newest Research Core Facility, the X-ray Microanalysis Core. Since it?s opening, this lab has become a centerpiece of MU advertising, and has been the featured photograph on the landing page of missouri.edu (screen capture image included here, copyright by the Curators of the University of Missouri).
